executable.title: PETCTCOSEG
executable.description: This is a CLI module that can be bundled in an extension
executable.contributor: Qi Song (University of Iowa), Junjie Bai (University of Iowa)

image.name: inputVolume_PET
image.label: Input Volume PET
image.description: PET image registered to CT image (withsame voxel spacing and image size)

image.name: inputVolume_OBJ
image.label: Input Volume OBJ
image.description: Object label seed image. A binary image containing only 1 and 0 intensities. All 1-voxels are definitely labeled as ‘object/foreground’ in segmentation. In this paper, one/multiple spheres (see ‘MultiSeeds’ field in configuration file explanation), where all voxels inside the spheres are 1, and all other voxels are 0.

image.name: inputVolume_BKG
image.label: Input Volume BKG
image.description: Background label seed image. A binary image with only 1 and 0 intensities. All 0-voxels (note it’s not 1-voxels!!!) are definitely labeled as ‘background’ in segmentation. In another word, the 1-voxels define a region which covers all tumor volumes. In this paper, a concentric larger sphere is used as bg seed for every ob seed sphere.

image.name: outputVolume_CTMP0
image.label: Output Volume CTMP0
image.description: Morphological operations are taken to ensure that only the largest connected component is kept in the final segmentation. Use this output segmentation if only one tumor volume is present in the image/ob seed image.

image.name: outputVolume_CTMP1
image.label: Output Volume CTMP1
image.description: No morphological operations are taken, keeping all connected components in final segmentation. Use this output segmentation if multiple tumor volumes are present in the image/ob seed image.

integer.name: flag_MultiSeeds
integer.description: 0/1 value.If 0, then morphological operations are taken to ensure that only the largest connected component is kept in the final segmentation. Use this value if only one tumor volume is present in the image/ob seed image. If 1, then no such morphological operations are taken, keeping all connected components in final segmentation. Use this value if multiple tumor volumes are present in the image/ob seed image.
integer.label: flag_MultiSeeds

integer.name: with_Context
integer.description: 0/1 value. If 1, co-segmentation is making use of both PET and CT images for segmentation. You should always use this value if you want to run co-segmentation. If 0, no context information is enforced between PET and CT, resulting in independent tumor segmentations based only on one modality. This value is only used for debugging purposes, because it shows how independent segmentation, based on just PET, or based on just CT, looks like.
integer.label: with_Context

integer.name: Context_Coef
integer.description: Multiplicative coefficient which controls how strong the PET-CT context constraints are. The larger the value is, the stronger it’s encouraged to have PET co-seg volume agree with CT co-seg volume. If set to extremely big value, this would effectively enforce PET co- seg volume to be the same as CT co-seg. This would be equivalent to performing a graph-cut segmentation on a fused PET-CT image. To make co-seg work best, you should set this value to a medium value, instead of extremely large or small values.
integer.label: Context_Coef

float.name: up_Thres
float.description: Float value within range [0,1]. All PET intensities larger than SUVUpThres*maxPETIntnesity is set to a saturated PET region cost, indicating it’s very likely to be tumor. See paper for moredetails.
float.label: up_Thres

float.name: low_Thres
float.description: Float value within range [0,1]. All PET intensities smaller than SUVLowThres*maxPETIntnesity is set to a saturated PET region cost, indicating it’s very likely to be not tumor. See paper for more details.
float.label: low_Thres
